body:
What's the output of:
```
ls -l $(brew --repo homebrew/cask)
```
? If you get a "No such file or directory", `brew tap homebrew/cask` and try again.

This is unfortunately expected behavior when using the API and not having `homebrew/core` and/or `homebrew/cask` tapped locally. Essentially the cat command is failing because those files don't exist locally anymore.

If you want to look at the source for a package, you need to either tap the about mentioned main taps again or you can use the `brew info --github` command to open the source in your browser.

Longer term I think that messaging for this command could be improved. In the event of an error we could check if the user is using the API, check if one of the formulae/casks is from a main tap, and then give a more helpful warning or even suggest using the `brew info --github` command instead.

labels.name: outdated
labels.description: PR was locked due to age

labels.name: critical
labels.description: Critical change which should be shipped as soon as possible.

repository.name: brew
repository.description: ðŸº The missing package manager for macOS (or Linux)

body:
> What's the output of:
> 
> ```
> ls -l $(brew --repo homebrew/cask)
> ```
> 
> ? If you get a "No such file or directory", `brew tap homebrew/cask` and try again.

```shell
ls -l $(brew --repo homebrew/cask)

"/opt/homebrew/Library/Taps/homebrew/homebrew-cask": No such file or directory (os error 2)
```

This result is expected because here it is suggested to remove the core and cask repo:


https://brew.sh/2023/02/16/homebrew-4.0.0/

> Unless you are developing formulae or casks, you can `brew untap homebrew/core` and `brew untap homebrew/cask` to save some space.

since i not develop them - I only like to see them I followed this instructions

I am as a user expect the `cat` command should work either, when I use the API or not.

When I install a formula/cask, then the formula/cask is downloaded from the API and executed.

Why the `cat` command also not use the same methods which are used in `brew install` to fetch the formula and display it for me?
I would like to reopen this issue. Just having a detailed error message not fix the problem that `brew cat` not display the formula/cask for my (regardless if it is on disc or not)

> Why the `cat` command also not use the same methods which are used in `brew install` to fetch the formula and display it for me?

The `install` command does not load most formulae/casks directly from the source file in the way I think you're assuming, so it's not possible to just download the source using "the same methods" in the way you suggest.

Also, note that `brew cat` is a developer command so I think it's reasonable for us to say that those who are running it on formulae/casks in `homebrew/core` or `homebrew/cask` have those tapped installed locally.

As an alternative, try `brew info --github virtualbox` or querying directly from GitHub.

To be a little more specific the package definition is loaded from JSON sent from the API so the original Ruby package definition is literally not available locally when using the API with the core taps untapped.

> Also, note that `brew cat` is a developer command so I think it's reasonable for us to say that those who are running it on formulae/casks in `homebrew/core` or `homebrew/cask` have those tapped installed locally.

Agreed. 

Sorry, passing on reopening this.

IMO `brew cat` isn't just a developer command. It's a one stop shop for all sorts of info: how does it install/uninstall, security red flags?, links, auto update?, version, etc.

Is there a reason why the command shouldn't be changed to work when using the API? This might inform which "solution" is ideal.

Possible ideas:
- dump a link to docs that explain the (potential) problem:
  `read more about this: <docs link>`
  - or, link to this issue #14815
  - or #14824
- mention alternative `brew info --github foo`
  - and/or print the github link
  - open the link
  - curl the link and pipe to STDOUT :)
    - optional - add a warning message that the source is not local... 
    - __ this would be my first choice __
- if source must be local then, mention:
  `brew tap X is required`

> IMO `brew cat` isn't just a developer command.

We disagree.

> Is there a reason why the command shouldn't be changed to work when using the API?

It could be improved, sure. We'll review a PR!

> * mention alternative `brew info --github foo`

Seems like a good idea.

There is also APIs to pull from the `raw.githubusercontent` domain that could be used here. I just went for the simplest thing to improve the error message here. Happy to provide more pointers.

issue.title: when `brew cat` fails, suggest `brew info --github`

issue.body:
When `brew cat formula|cask` fails, add suggestion to use `brew info --github formula|cask` instead. This gives a workaround for API users that don't have taps locally for `homebrew/core` and `homebrew/cask`.

This builds on changes from #14824 which addressed #14815

body: What is more inconsistent: when a formula/cask is installed then `brew cat` don't give an error

> There is also APIs to pull from the `raw.githubusercontent` domain that could be used here.

That can be used to display the formula in with `brew cat` then I think that's a better solution that an error message ðŸ‘

I agree that using raw.guthubusercontent would be a better solution. An
actionable error message is just a stopgap.

issue.title: Unify formula and cask API source download handling

labels.name: outdated
labels.description: PR was locked due to age

repository.name: brew
repository.description: ðŸº The missing package manager for macOS (or Linux)

issue.body:
### Verification

- [X] This issue's title and/or description do not reference a single formula e.g. `brew install wget`. If they do, open an issue at https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core/issues/new/choose instead.

### Provide a detailed description of the proposed feature

The formula way to handle downloads is fully fleshed out with progress information and the cask system is not. The stage where the download occurs is also different. It's worth consolidating the two.

### What is the motivation for the feature?

* Improved UX for cask source downloads
* More common shared code (better maintainability)

### How will the feature be relevant to at least 90% of Homebrew users?

The UX for cask source downloads is poor in that there is no progress information and it happens too regularly. Fixing that will provide a better experience.

### What alternatives to the feature have been considered?

Keep it separate and just modify the cask side for feature parity.
